awd_titl_txt: Growing the Community College Pipeline for Careers in Civil, Chemical, and Ocean Engineering through the FITS-STEM Program
awd_abstract_narration:
The Florida Institute of Technology (FIT) is supporting 26 academically talented transfer students with financial need who are majoring in chemical, civil, and ocean engineering through this S-STEM project.  Three cohorts of transfer students from community colleges and four-year state colleges that do not offer engineering degrees are supported through scholarships, early mentoring, and other academic and career support activities.  FIT is leveraging partnerships with five colleges (Eastern Florida State College - formerly Brevard Community College, Indian River State College, Daytona State College, Hillsborough Community College, and Miami Dade College) to provide students opportunities to transfer to FIT and pursue engineering degrees to address workforce needs in the state of Florida.  The project outcomes include increasing the number of transfer students from low income groups to enter STEM fields, improving opportunities for underrepresented minority students to obtain STEM degrees, helping partner schools recruit more students in STEM fields, and disseminating the lessons learned and evaluation results of the project.  

FIT is implementing a comprehensive set of evidence-based practices to support the successful transfer, retention, and graduation of its transfer students.  The project includes a focused recruitment plan at the partner colleges.  The early mentoring and transition support provided while students are at the community and state colleges aims to smooth the transition process.  Established articulation agreements between FIT and the partner community colleges and four-year institutions are leveraged as well.  While enrolled at FIT, students participate in multiple cohort building and professional development activities, including hands-on activities with student engineering professional organizations, sustainability-related design and research seminars, and also have opportunities to engage in regional and national student competitions and use services provided by the Enhanced Academic Support Center.  In addition, career advising activities assist the students' transition into the engineering workforce.  The project includes an evaluation plan with both formative and summative evaluation via mixed methods (such as surveys and interviews) to identify improvements to the FITS-STEM scholarship program, as well as multiple metrics to track success in meeting project outcomes.

por.por_cntn:
Background

The main purpose of this award was to provide two-year scholarships (the scholarship amount was $5k over four semesters for a total of $20k per student) to deserving transfer students from Community and State Colleges and get them ready for the STEM-world through a carefully implemented program which consisted of several plans to help students overcome the transition from a Community/State College to a private University with strong academic standards. To develop cohesive cohorts, only students who applied to Chemical Engineering, Civil Engineering and Ocean Engineering were selected as students in these three majors share coursework and research activities. Thirty-one students were provided scholarships through the NSF STEM award; ten students in Chemical Engineering, eight students in Civil Engineering, and 13 students in Ocean Engineering. The following plans were implemented:

  • Early Mentoring and Transition Plan: The main features of this plan were to : 1) Guide the students through Orientation Week activities, 2) have advisor meetings to design Academic Program Plans that would ensure that students graduated in a timely manner, and 3) Meetings with a financial aid office representative to confirm the financial aid package and to go over academic requirements to maintain their scholarship through the STEM grant.
  • Cohort Plan (CP): The main feature of this plan was to progressively convert the FITS-STEM cohort into a community of scholars through self-motivation and peer-motivation. This was done by 1) providing a delegated space for social and professional networking opportunities with peers, 2) providing bonding opportunities via voluntary fun activities related to sustainability, 3) providing opportunities to do multi-disciplinary sustainability related research, 4) providing opportunities to do multi-disciplinary sustainability related capstone design projects, and 5) providing enhanced tutoring services in advanced level courses.
  • Career Advising Plan (CAP): Through this plan, students were encouraged to attend  number of events are held by FIT?s Career Management Services (CMS) to assist students in seeking and obtaining suitable jobs. Some of these events dealt with activities such as Resume Writing, Interviewing Techniques, Job Search Strategies and Networking, Mock Interviews etc.
  • Maintenance Plan (MP): The purpose of the Maintenance Plan was to systematically record student activities such as participation in seminars, social events, orientation week, research etc. to provide formative assessment to the FITS-STEM team for review and decision making.

 

During the course of this project, we recruited six cohorts, one each in AY 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020 and 2022. We were unable to recruit a cohort in 2021 because of issues related to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Key Outcomes

  • Of the 31 students who have enrolled in the STEM Program, 19 students have graduated, six students were not able to complete the program or transferred to a non-STEM major, and six students remain in their respective program.
  • Most of the transfer students in these cohorts performed exceptionally well. The range of CGPA for the 19 students who graduated by Spring 2022 ranged from 2.36 to 3.90 with an average CGPA of 3.22. This average for the FIT-STEM student is higher than the average CGPA of other students which is around 2.9.
  • Ten of the graduating students had a CGPA of greater than 3.5.
  • One of the students was selected as the senior student-of-the year in the entire University.
  • All the graduated students have found suitable employment are have joined a STEM related graduate program including Engineering Management, or MBA programs

Key Findings

 

  • The six students who were unable to graduate, mostly because of academic issues, were all handicapped by part-time work which they continued to perform despite the STEM award. The part-time jobs often required 10-20 hours per week and were the main reasons for students not being able to find sufficient time to cope with academics. Most of them were off-campus students.
  • The students showed diverse interests. Most were enthusiastic about career advising and attended several of the events are held by FIT?s Career Management Services. Many the cohort students were interested in Sustainability related research and Program related student chapter activities.
  • Most of the cohort students made sub-groups to study together and developed strong friendships. A couple even got married.
  • The designated space allotted to the students was seldom used. Instead students chose to meet at other places of convenience to study.
  • It was difficult for all students to be physically present for all of the organized activities. While this was a problem in the early years, this was not a major issue during COVID and post-COVID as the students were given the option for virtual participation.
  • Some of the students did request, and were provided, enhanced academic support
  • E-mails have been received from several students thanking us for the STEM award and acknowledging that they would not have been able to graduate without the financial support through the STEM award.

 


Last Modified: 02/15/2023
Modified by: Ashok Pandit
por.por_txt_cntn:
Background

The main purpose of this award was to provide two-year scholarships (the scholarship amount was $5k over four semesters for a total of $20k per student) to deserving transfer students from Community and State Colleges and get them ready for the STEM-world through a carefully implemented program which consisted of several plans to help students overcome the transition from a Community/State College to a private University with strong academic standards. To develop cohesive cohorts, only students who applied to Chemical Engineering, Civil Engineering and Ocean Engineering were selected as students in these three majors share coursework and research activities. Thirty-one students were provided scholarships through the NSF STEM award; ten students in Chemical Engineering, eight students in Civil Engineering, and 13 students in Ocean Engineering. The following plans were implemented:

Early Mentoring and Transition Plan: The main features of this plan were to : 1) Guide the students through Orientation Week activities, 2) have advisor meetings to design Academic Program Plans that would ensure that students graduated in a timely manner, and 3) Meetings with a financial aid office representative to confirm the financial aid package and to go over academic requirements to maintain their scholarship through the STEM grant.
Cohort Plan (CP): The main feature of this plan was to progressively convert the FITS-STEM cohort into a community of scholars through self-motivation and peer-motivation. This was done by 1) providing a delegated space for social and professional networking opportunities with peers, 2) providing bonding opportunities via voluntary fun activities related to sustainability, 3) providing opportunities to do multi-disciplinary sustainability related research, 4) providing opportunities to do multi-disciplinary sustainability related capstone design projects, and 5) providing enhanced tutoring services in advanced level courses. 


Career Advising Plan (CAP): Through      this plan, students were encouraged to attend  number of events are held by FIT?s Career      Management Services (CMS) to assist students in seeking and obtaining      suitable jobs. Some of these events dealt with activities such as Resume      Writing, Interviewing Techniques, Job Search Strategies and Networking,      Mock Interviews etc.
Maintenance Plan (MP): The purpose of the Maintenance Plan was to systematically      record student activities such as participation in seminars, social      events, orientation week, research etc. to provide formative assessment to      the FITS-STEM team for review and decision making.


 

During the course of this project, we recruited six cohorts, one each in AY 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020 and 2022. We were unable to recruit a cohort in 2021 because of issues related to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Key Outcomes 

Of the 31 students who have enrolled in the STEM Program, 19 students have graduated, six students were not able to complete the program or transferred to a non-STEM major, and six students remain in their respective program.
Most of the transfer students in these cohorts performed exceptionally well. The range of CGPA for the 19 students who graduated by Spring 2022 ranged from 2.36 to 3.90 with an average CGPA of 3.22. This average for the FIT-STEM student is higher than the average CGPA of other students which is around 2.9.
Ten of the graduating students had a CGPA of greater than 3.5.
One of the students was selected as the senior student-of-the year in the entire University.
All the graduated students have found suitable employment are have joined a STEM related graduate program including Engineering Management, or MBA programs 


Key Findings

 

The six students who were unable to graduate, mostly because of academic issues, were all handicapped by part-time work which they continued to perform despite the STEM award. The part-time jobs often required 10-20 hours per week and were the main reasons for students not being able to find sufficient time to cope with academics. Most of them were off-campus students.
The students showed diverse interests. Most were enthusiastic about career advising and attended several of the events are held by FIT?s Career Management Services. Many the cohort students were interested in Sustainability related research and Program related student chapter activities.
Most of the cohort students made sub-groups to study together and developed strong friendships. A couple even got married. 
The designated space allotted to the students was seldom used. Instead students chose to meet at other places of convenience to study.
It was difficult for all students to be physically present for all of the organized activities. While this was a problem in the early years, this was not a major issue during COVID and post-COVID as the students were given the option for virtual participation.
Some of the students did request, and were provided, enhanced academic support
E-mails have been received from several students thanking us for the STEM award and acknowledging that they would not have been able to graduate without the financial support through the STEM award.
